abstract: CESSNA DELIVERS VERY LIGHT JET As the very light jet market stirs to life, the Cessna Aircraft Company delivered its first retail Citation Mustang jet last week to Goode Ski Technologies. Goode is currently flying a Cessna 310 twin-engine piston propeller aircraft, and says it bought the Mustang to make it easier to travel to ski locations to test its products. Cessna already has two Mustangs flying for marketing purposes. The $2.5 million, four-passenger Mustang is the latest model of a very light jet to enter commercial service. Eclipse Aviation recently delivered three of its Eclipse 500 very light jets to DayJet, a company that plans to begin on-demand air-taxi service in June and has ordered 239 of the aircraft. Competitors producing very light jets, which are sometimes called microjets, include Adam Aircraft, Honda, Embraer and Piper. A new online magazine, www.verylightjets.com, is devoted exclusively to the new aircraft.

abstract: Wages in Japan fell for a fourth month in March, signaling that growth in consumer spending will be limited. Monthly wages, including overtime and bonuses, fell 0.4 percent after dropping 1 percent in February, the labor ministry said. In China, manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in more than two years in April, according to a survey of purchasing managers. The Purchasing Managers’ Index rose to 58.6 from 56.1 in March, the statistics bureau said. That is the highest since the index started in January 2005.

abstract: In “Mindless Eating” (Bantam Books, 2006), the Cornell professor Brian Wansink explains the psychological cues that lead people to overeat. The human stomach isn’t sensitive enough to notice small caloric differences, and it often doesn’t register how much has been eaten until 20 minutes or more after the food has been swallowed. So people instead rely on their eyes, ears and noses to tell them when to stop eating. And they often overeat as a result.

So people instead rely on their eyes, ears and noses to tell them when to stop eating. And they often overeat as a result.

abstract: How hot is the mergers and acquisitions market? Consider this: April marked an all-time high for the value of worldwide mergers announced in a single month, lifted in large part by a bidding war that broke out for Dutch bank ABN Amro. Thomson Financial calculates that the combined value of deals announced last month came to $626.3 billion, surpassing the previous record of $518.1 billion set in January 2000, when America Online  announced its $165 billion bid for Time Warner.

abstract: Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. At $60 per share, it was 67 percent above the company’s recent stock price and represented a multiple of about 16 times Dow Jones’s projected 2007 Ebitda. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid “absolutely, insanely high.”
lead_paragraph: Many Wall Street analysts are still gaping over the $5 billion unsolicited bid that Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation made for Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal. (Other recent newspaper deals have come in at about eight times Ebitda.) A former financial adviser to the Bancroft family, which controls Dow Jones, has called the bid “absolutely, insanely high.”

Brookfield Asset, based in Toronto, will hold a 40 percent stake in the new company. Brookfield Asset also said it would split its shares 3-for-2.

abstract: Shareholders of Dow Jones & Company, whose stock price until recently has languished in the mid-30’s, are not the only ones that could see a windfall if the company ends up being acquired by News Corporation at $60 per share. The deal is far from certain: A majority of the Bancroft family, which has a controlling interest in the company, currently stands opposed to Rupert Murdoch’s proposal. Still, The New York Times’s Eric Dash looked through regulatory filings and found that a sale, if it happened, might mean multimillion-dollar paydays for the top managers of Dow Jones, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal.

abstract: Let’s face it: It’s hard out there for an analyst who wants to stand out from the crowd, especially if you stick to the standard buy-hold-sell script. Last year, a Credit Suisse semiconductor analyst, Mike Masdea, shook things up with a mass voicemail to clients in which he imitated rapper Eminem as he gave his take on the chip business. The voicemail made the rounds on Wall Street and was preserved for posterity on Dealbreaker. (“Masdea may want to check himself before he wrecks himself,” one trader quipped to the New York Post.)

Jim Amine, who had been co-head of European global markets solutions with Mr. Raphael, takes over as the group’s sole head.

abstract: Private equity firms have historically looked askance at technology companies, whose volatile earnings don’t always mix nicely with heavy debt loads. Which is why the recent findings by Jason Bazinet, a media analyst at Citigroup, are fairly remarkable. Using what he called “fairly conservative assumptions,” Mr. Bazinet screened 100 global media stocks and decided that most of them are not likely to be targets of a leveraged buyout offer anytime soon. Of those that made the cut, however, most were Internet companies.

abstract: The Supreme Court of Canada rejected an appeal from Wal-Mart Canada over efforts to unionize another store in Quebec. As is always the case, the high court offered no reasons for its decision. The court’s move appears to open the way for the automatic certification of a store in Gatineau, a city across a river from Ottawa. “We’re disappointed but not surprised, because the Supreme Court rarely hears cases like this,” said Yanik Deschênes, a spokesman for Wal-Mart. Wal-Mart wanted a court order requiring that Quebec’s labor board conduct a secret ballot of employees. The United Food and Commercial Workers has asked for automatic certification under Quebec law based on the number of union membership cards it signed at the outlet.

abstract: With the Motorola proxy showdown set for Monday, billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn appears to have a new ally. ClearBridge Advisors, a money manager owned by brokerage firm Legg Mason, said it would support his bid for a seat on the cellphone maker’s board — something the company has adamantly opposed in a series of increasingly hard-edged announcements. “Given recent events at the company, we believe it is in the best interest of all shareholders to have a new representative on the board,” ClearBridge said in a press release. The firm did not say which “events” it had in mind, but Motorola has been struggling mightly in the past few months. In March, it slashed its revenue forecasts announced a management shake-up.
lead_paragraph: With the Motorola proxy showdown set for Monday, billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn appears to have a new ally. ClearBridge Advisors, a money manager owned by brokerage firm Legg Mason, said it would support his bid for a seat on the cellphone maker’s board — something the company has adamantly opposed in a series of increasingly hard-edged announcements. “Given recent events at the company, we believe it is in the best interest of all shareholders to have a new representative on the board,” ClearBridge said in a press release. The firm did not say which “events” it had in mind, but Motorola has been struggling mightly in the past few months. In March, it slashed its revenue forecasts announced a management shake-up.

headline.main: A $1 Billion Vote of Confidence for Icahn

abstract: Rupert Murdoch’s bombshell $5 billion bid for Dow Jones has a lot of legal types talking make-up. More specifically, they’re talking about Revlon, the subject of a 1985 ruling that helped define a corporate board’s duties when a company is up for sale. Dow Jones, like The New York Times Company and the Washington Post Company, has a dual-class share structure that gives majority voting power to its controlling family and insulates it from the whims of Wall Street. But the Bancroft family’s initial resistance to News Corp.’s overture raises questions. What are the board’s responsibilities when a controlling family rejects offers that minority shareholders would jump at? In particular, how do the so-called Revlon duties play into these situations?
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch’s bombshell $5 billion bid for Dow Jones has a lot of legal types talking make-up. More specifically, they’re talking about Revlon, the subject of a 1985 ruling that helped define a corporate board’s duties when a company is up for sale. Dow Jones, like The New York Times Company and the Washington Post Company, has a dual-class share structure that gives majority voting power to its controlling family and insulates it from the whims of Wall Street. But the Bancroft family’s initial resistance to News Corp.’s overture raises questions. What are the board’s responsibilities when a controlling family rejects offers that minority shareholders would jump at? In particular, how do the so-called Revlon duties play into these situations?

headline.main: Can Dow Jones’s Board ‘Just Say No’?

abstract: The Dutch bank ABN Amro, the subject of one of the largest takeover battles in history, said Monday it had rejected a $24.5 billion offer for its Lasalle Bank subisidiary from a group including the Royal Bank of Scotland, finding it “did not constitute a superior proposal” to a previous bid from Bank of America. Nevertheless, ABN said it would allow shareholders to vote on the competing bid and others, as required by last week’s ruling in an Amsterdam court.

abstract: Alcoa, the world’s No. 1 aluminum company, said Monday it would make an unsolicited bid it valued at $33 billion for Alcan, a Montreal-based rival. Alcoa said the proposed bid came after lengthy negotiations between the two aluminum giants failed to produce a mutually agreed deal. “This offer follows almost two years of discussions between our companies regarding a variety of potential business combination transactions, including unsuccessful board-level discussions of a merger transaction last fall,” Alcoa’s chief executive Alain J.P. Belda said in a statement. “We are very disappointed that those efforts did not result in a negotiated transaction — a conclusion we would have strongly preferred.”

abstract: Could Nicolas Sarkozy inspire American Republicans?
snippet: Could Nicolas Sarkozy inspire American Republicans?
lead_paragraph: Jacques Chirac leaves office after two terms as France’s president, largely deemed a failure. He gets credit in France for standing up to President Bush over Iraq, but on the domestic front it was a time of drift, with efforts on reform collapsing as soon as protesters took to the streets. Voters rejected the European Union constitution he supported. He decided against seeking a third term only when polls made clear he could not win.

headline.main: Sarkozy’s Lesson for Republicans

abstract: Alcan, the Montreal-based aluminum giant, had a relatively low-key public reaction Monday to Alcoa’s surprise $33 billion hostile bid, saying in a short press release that it would “consider the proposal.” Canadian politicians may not be so measured. The uninvited offer from Alcoa, which is based in Pittsburgh, is likely to rekindle a national debate in Canada about the recent surge in foreign takeovers of large Canadian companies and whether it represents a threat to the country’s economic prestige — not to mention a potential loss of lucrative underwriting, accounting and legal work for the nation’s financial professionals.

abstract: Private equity chiefs worried about a much bigger tax bite can take some comfort — though it’s unclear just how much — from Senate Finance Committee Chairman Max Baucus. The Democratic lawmaker from Montana told the National Press Club on Monday that his committee is “nowhere close” to drafting a bill that could affect the amount of tax that private equity funds and hedge funds have to pay. Mr. Baucus called recent reports that such legislation is already being drafted “pure speculation,” according to Bloomberg. “People need to keep their shirts on here.”

abstract: The Macquarie Bank, Australia’s largest securities firm, made a new takeover offer for the energy transmission company Alinta to challenge Alinta’s agreement to be acquired for 7.4 billion Australian dollars ($6.1 billion) by Babcock & Brown and Singapore Power. Alinta, based in Perth, Australia, is seeking further information on the revised offer. Macquarie, based in Sydney, said its proposal included three options, one of them an all-cash bid. Macquarie did not disclose further details. Both Macquarie and Babcock plan to break up the utility, which has a nationwide network of gas and power lines, and generates electricity at five plants. Alinta rejected Macquarie’s earlier offer on March 30.

abstract: Webdenda.
snippet: Webdenda.
lead_paragraph: The Advertising Club, New York, presented the 2007 International Andy Awards for campaigns that appeared in 2006. For the first time, the Best of Show Award, known as the Grandy, was presented to a digital campaign. The winning agency, R/GA, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was honored for work for Nike Plus, the running shoe that comes with an iPod Nano. The campaign also won another award, sponsored by Yahoo, called the Big Idea Chair. Offices of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, won the most Andys, 14, followed by offices of Leo Burnett Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe, with 10. The honor for best in show for public service advertising, known as the Richard T. O’Reilly Award, went to the “Truth” anti-smoking campaign created by Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners division of Havas, and Crispin Porter & Bogusky, Miami, part of MDC Partners.

abstract: Deal making in the metals sector is flourishing. abstract: Australia’s richest man, James Packer, will split his Publishing & Broadcasting empire into two listed gaming and media companies and return 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.7 billion) to shareholders, sending the firm’s stock up 6 percent, Reuters reported Tuesday. abstract: Kenneth Griffin doesn’t shy away from unloved assets. As the market for subprime mortgages — loans to homeowners with weak credit histories — began to fall apart this year, his $13.5 billion fund, the Citadel Investment Group, snapped up assets in the industry. Now, Citadel is putting a chunk of money into a beaten-down technology company. Citadel has spent $135 million to buy an 8.4 percent stake in 3Com, a maker of networking equipment that was a Wall Street darling in the 1990’s, before it spun off its Palm subsidiary and the technology boom subsided. Times have changed, and 3com’s stock has lost about half its value since early 2004.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Griffin doesn’t shy away from unloved assets. Citadel has spent $135 million to buy an 8.4 percent stake in 3Com, a maker of networking equipment that was a Wall Street darling in the 1990’s, before it spun off its Palm subsidiary and the technology boom subsided. Times have changed, and 3com’s stock has lost about half its value since early 2004.

headline.main: Citadel Gets Active With Networking Firm 3Com

abstract: Since it was founded a year and a half ago with a roster of brand-name investment bankers, Perella Weinberg Partners has left many on Wall Street wondering when it would get its first marquee deal — the kind of blockbuster transaction that involves well-known companies and lots of zeroes in the price tag. On Tuesday, the doubters seemed to get their answer: The boutique investment bank, led by Joseph R. Perella, is a co-lead adviser to the Thomson Corporation, alongside Bear Stearns, in its negotiations to acquire the Reuters Group for 8.77 billion pounds ($17.5 billion).

abstract: Some top universities may be getting caught up in a wide-ranging congressional examination of the tax treatment of hedge funds and private equity firms. The scrutiny from Washington has been a prime concern for many buyout chiefs, who fear that cherished tax loopholes may be closed. (PEhub, writing about the topic Tuesday, poked some fun at such concerns, noting “the horror of being filthy rich instead of obscenely rich.”) On Tuesday, Bloomberg News reported that, in addition to looking at how private equity and hedge funds are taxed, the Senate Finance Committee also discussed offshore investments of pension funds, foundations and universities including Harvard, Yale and Stanford.

abstract: Well, that was fast. Less than a week after Dow Jones confirmed receiving a $5 billion takeover bid from News Corporation, a Hong Kong couple stands accused of insider trading in Dow Jones shares before the approach was made public. In a civil complaint filed Tuesday in New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission said the couple spent $15 million to engage in “highly profitable and highly suspicious” trades in Dow Jones shares from April 13 to April 30. When the bid was announced on May 1, Dow Jones’s shares shot up by 58 percent.
lead_paragraph: Well, that was fast. Less than a week after Dow Jones confirmed receiving a $5 billion takeover bid from News Corporation, a Hong Kong couple stands accused of insider trading in Dow Jones shares before the approach was made public. In a civil complaint filed Tuesday in New York, the Securities and Exchange Commission said the couple spent $15 million to engage in “highly profitable and highly suspicious” trades in Dow Jones shares from April 13 to April 30. When the bid was announced on May 1, Dow Jones’s shares shot up by 58 percent.

headline.main: 2 Accused of Insider Trading in Dow Jones Stock

abstract: Richard Grasso’s retirement may have just gotten a bit more pleasant. The former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange won a partial legal victory on Tuesday when an appeals court threw out four rulings against him in a suit over his $190 compensation package. The reversal was on technical grounds, The Associated Press said; Bloomberg News reported that the state of New York can still go to trial against Mr. Grasso on other claims. A spokesman for New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, as New York’s attorney general, first sued Mr. Grasso to seek the return of the money, said the state planned to appeal Tuesday’s decision. But the final decision on an appeal will be up to New York’s current attorney general, Andrew Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: Richard Grasso’s retirement may have just gotten a bit more pleasant. The former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange won a partial legal victory on Tuesday when an appeals court threw out four rulings against him in a suit over his $190 compensation package. The reversal was on technical grounds, The Associated Press said; Bloomberg News reported that the state of New York can still go to trial against Mr. Grasso on other claims. A spokesman for New York Governor Eliot Spitzer, who, as New York’s attorney general, first sued Mr. Grasso to seek the return of the money, said the state planned to appeal Tuesday’s decision. But the final decision on an appeal will be up to New York’s current attorney general, Andrew Cuomo.

headline.main: Grasso Wins Round in Lawsuit Over Pay

abstract: Cravath Swaine & Moore, the New York law firm, is putting its white shoe firmly in the bankruptcy business. The firm, which frequently counsels companies in multibillion-dollar mergers, said Wednesday it has formed a corporate restructuring and insolvency group and hired Richard Levin, a former partner at Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom, to lead it. The move comes as Skadden and other law firms with established restructuring practices have been recruiting new talent, anticipating that the long lull in large corporate bankruptcies might be nearing an end.

abstract: South Korea plans to break ground for the world’s biggest solar power plant as it tries to diversify its power sources and use cleaner energy, the government and developers said. The $170 million plant, being built in Shinan, near the southwestern tip of South Korea, is part of an effort to seek new and renewable energy sources and is scheduled to be completed by late 2008. The plant will produce more than 27,000 megawatt-hours of electricity a year, enough to supply 6,000 to 7,000 households, said Kim Ji Hun, president of the Korean subsidiary of SunTechnics, the German solar power company that will build the plant. It will be operated by Dongyang Engineering and Construction.

abstract: Enel, an Italian utility, said first-quarter profit unexpectedly rose 12 percent, fueled by increased foreign sales and cost cuts. Net income climbed to 943 million euros ($1.28 billion), or 16 cents a share, from 842 million euros, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. Enel, which is bidding for the Spanish utility Endesa, sold power in Eastern Europe and Russia in the period to make up for falling electricity demand at home. Costs were reduced by 7.2 percent, helping offset a drop in Italian sales. Sales declined 5.1 percent, to 9.73 billion euros. The bid for Endesa values the company at 43.7 billion euros and will give Enel access to another 22 million customers. The deal will create a platform to sell electricity across borders when the EU energy market opens to competition on July 1.

abstract: BNP Paribas, the French bank, reported a 25 percent increase in first-quarter profit on higher corporate and investment bank earnings and gains from asset sales. Income climbed to 2.51 billion euros ($3.4 billion), from 2.01 billion euros a year earlier, BNP Paribas said. Revenue rose 21 percent, to 8.21 billion euros. Profit beat the 2.06 billion euros expected by analysts. BNP Paribas’s stock rose 3.65 euros, to 91.15 euros. Pretax profit at the corporate and investment bank rose 12 percent. Earnings at the French branch network declined 2.2 percent, while pretax profit at BancWest, a unit based in Hawaii, slipped 20 percent. Excluding Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, earnings at BNP Paribas’s international retail bank decreased 5.3 percent.

abstract: Windows Mobile 6 is now available as a free download for owners of the T-Mobile Dash.

lead_paragraph: You’ll never be able to buy a boxed version of Microsoft’s latest mobile operating system, but who needs boxes? Windows Mobile 6, a considerable upgrade to the company’s operating system for smartphones and P.D.A.’s, is now available as a free download for owners of the T-Mobile Dash. Versions will soon be released for other smartphones, old and new, from multiple carriers.

abstract: Venture investors are searching for a new model for alternative energy deals, and partnerships with private equity funds may be part of the solution, The Deal reports. These investors want to get high returns on early developments so they are not diluted when the time comes for raising capital for building production facilities. Volatile energy prices only add to the uncertainty. “It’s a very difficult balancing act for venture capital investors in energy right now,” the head of the energy ventures group at Portland, Ore.-based law firm Stoel Rives tells The Deal.

abstract: General Electric said Wednesday that it had paid 126.3 billion yen ($1.05 billion) for the Japanese leasing company Sanyo Electric Credit. G.E. paid 3,250 yen a share for 97 percent of Sanyo Credit’s stock, the company said. The company bought the shares from Sanyo Electric and two Goldman Sachs units. G.E. is focusing on lending to companies after the Japanese government tightened consumer credit rules.

abstract: The pace of mergers and acquisitions in the biotechnology industry is expected to continue at a torrid pace through 2007, said panelists at the Biotechnology Industry Organization conference in Boston on Wednesday. abstract: Many in Hong Kong were surprised to learn that a local aristocrat and business magnate, David K.P. Li, may come under scrutiny in relation to stock trading ahead of Rupert Murdoch’s $5 billion for Dow Jones. But the investigation by American regulators into the possible leak of confidential information could have wider effects, potentially damaging the city’s attempts to shake its reputation for financial regulations that are weaker than the West’s, The New York Times reports. Hong Kong only made insider trading a criminal offense in 2003, and has not yet brought any prosecutions under the statute.
lead_paragraph: Many in Hong Kong were surprised to learn that a local aristocrat and business magnate, David K.P. Hong Kong only made insider trading a criminal offense in 2003, and has not yet brought any prosecutions under the statute.

headline.main: Dow Jones Inquiry Could Be Awkward for Hong Kong

abstract: In an era of skyrocketing pay for chief executives and growing shareholder angst about it, a handful of C.E.O.s are opting to draw a $1 paycheck or none at all. abstract: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Hugh Scott-Barrett, would resign in August. News of Mr. Scott-Barrett’s departure came as ABN is trying to fend off an unsolicited $98 billion takeover approach so it can be acquired in a friendly deal by Barclays of Britain. ABN said late Wednesday it would appeal a decision in a Dutch court that halted the sale of the LaSalle Bank, its Chicago subsidiary, to the Bank of America. That side deal was widely seen as an attempt to drive off the rival bidding group, led by the Royal Bank of Scotland.
lead_paragraph: ABN Amro, the Dutch bank at the center of one of the biggest bidding wars in history, said Thursday that its chief financial officer, Hugh Scott-Barrett, would resign in August. abstract: Even as its stock is riding high off the success of the iPod and anticipation of the iPhone, Apple will face some restive shareholders at its annual meeting Thursday, TheStreet.com reported. Labor unions who own Apple shares through pension funds, have put up proposals that require options to be priced on the day they are granted to eliminate the practice known as backdating; that give investors a nonbinding vote on executive compensation, known as “say on pay”; and that tie executive bonuses to the company’s stock performance.

abstract: There are dozens or hundreds of huge Web 2.0 ideas that have yet to materialize.
snippet: There are dozens or hundreds of huge Web 2.0 ideas that have yet to materialize.
lead_paragraph: "Web 2.0," as I understand it, refers to Web sites whose contents are supplied by us, the people. What would Flickr be without its photos, YouTube without the videos, Craigslist without the ads, eBay without the auctions, TripAdvisor without people's travel reviews? These mega-sites would be only empty white pages if the audience didn't supply their materials.

headline.main: Asking the Crowd to Spread the News
headline.kicker: From the Desk of David Pogue

abstract: Nine years after the math whizzes at Long Term Capital Management found themselves on the brink of a market-rattling collapse — which they narrowly averted thanks to a huge bailout by a consortium of banks — some of the hedge fund’s former employees are having a reunion of sorts. Bloomberg reports that Eric Rosenfeld, one of Long Term Capital’s co-founders, has joined with the fund’s former chief financial officer, Robert Shustak, and its former controller, Bruce Wilson, to open Quantitative Alternatives, which Bloomberg describes as a hedge fund that “uses computers to pick investments.” The fund apparently uses humans too: The Rye Brook, N.Y.-based firm is currently hiring research analysts and traders.
lead_paragraph: Nine years after the math whizzes at Long Term Capital Management found themselves on the brink of a market-rattling collapse — which they narrowly averted thanks to a huge bailout by a consortium of banks — some of the hedge fund’s former employees are having a reunion of sorts. headline.main: Long Term Capital Alumni Form New Fund

abstract: The speed with which the Securities and Exchange Commission identified and took action against alleged insider trading in Dow Jones stock this week was “a phenomenal achievement,” Harvey Pitt, the S.E.C.’s former chairman, declared in an interview with The Wall Street Journal’s Law Blog. Mr. Pitt, who served from 2001 to 2003, said that “in the old days, it took a while to figure out who knew what, when and where. I would say enforcement is alive and well.”

abstract: Facing criticism from unions and lawmakers, the private equity industry has found a passionate champion on the Internet. The only problem is that it’s unclear who that person is. Percywalker.com, a financial blog of murky provenance, has entered the debate on the taxation of “carried interest,” a big source of fees for the people who run private equity funds. The blog claims to be written by a billionaire named Percival X. Walker, but when contacted last year by Forbes magazine — which failed to find any mention of Mr. Walker in public documents — the operator of the blog said: “I lack the desire to establish that I even exist.”

abstract: Why did Overstock.com change its disclosure? It won’t say, but it did denounce me for asking.
snippet: Why did Overstock.com change its disclosure? It won’t say, but it did denounce me for asking.
lead_paragraph: Overstock.com, which has a huge short position, has drawn my attention a few times in the past. (For blogs, see here. For columns, see here, here, here, and here.) I am attracted to the story because Patrick Byrne, the chief executive, has engaged in what he called a jihad against naked short sellers, who sell the shares without borrowing them, and has had some political success. I am more impressed by his jihad-making activity than by his corporate management, but he is certainly different from your average chief executive. He has sued an analyst firm, a hedge fund and most of the major Wall Street firms. An S.E.C. investigation is pending.

headline.main: A Conspiracy So Vast

The move marked a turning point in the short history of the upstart airline, but it also gave new life to recent speculation that the low-cost carrier might be a candidate for a takeover. JetBlue’s shares rose 4.7 percent after the move was announced.

abstract: DaimlerChrysler confirmed Monday that it would sell a controlling interest in its struggling Chrysler Group to Cerberus Capital Management of New York, a private equity firm that specializes in restructuring troubled companies. The price being paid is $7.4 billion, mostly in the form of capital that Cerberus will put into Chrysler. Of that sum, DaimlerChrylser itself will receive only $1.3 billion, and the German automaker said Monday that the transaction will actually result in a “net cash outflow” of about $678 million.

abstract: The winner of the auction for Chrysler, Cerberus Capital Management, is widely refered to as a private equity shop these days. But the firm’s longtime legal adviser, Schulte Roth & Zabel, reflects Cerberus’s roots as a hedge fund — and one that knows its way around a bankruptcy courtroom. Schulte Roth, which counseled Cerberus in the Chrysler negotiations, is known as one of the top legal advisers to hedge funds, and it claims to represent more than one half of the 100 largest hedge funds listed in Institutional Investor. On many occasions, it has advised Cerberus when it bid for assets of bankrupt companies (or when Cerberus’s portfolio companies tumbled into bankruptcy protection themselves).

abstract: If Chrysler is worthless, why are Ford and GM shares up?
snippet: If Chrysler is worthless, why are Ford and GM shares up?
lead_paragraph: The most amazing aspect of Daimler’s giveaway of Chrysler is that it is considered good news by all. Ford and General Motors shares are up, despite the fact that Chrysler is deemed essentially worthless. Daimler bonds are up on the news, and the company’s bond rating may be increased, despite the fact that it no longer will have Chrysler assets available to help provide the money to repay the bonds.

headline.main: Take My Company, Please

abstract: As aluminum giant Alcan considers how to react to the hostile $27 billion from Alcoa, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group has a suggestion that harkens back to the era when legwarmers were the height of fashion (though we hear they are making a comeback). The analyst, John C. Tumazos, is floating the idea that terms of the deal could be flipped so that Montreal-based Alcan buys New York-based Alcoa. Such a tactic first gained currency in the 1980’s, when it became known as the Pac-Man defense, after the popular video game in which the player could change roles and go after his or her pursuers.
lead_paragraph: As aluminum giant Alcan considers how to react to the hostile $27 billion from Alcoa, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group has a suggestion that harkens back to the era when legwarmers were the height of fashion (though we hear they are making a comeback). headline.main: Should Alcan Turn the Tables on Alcoa?

abstract: If you own shares in a takeover target, you might want to pin your hopes on a public company being the buyer. That is because these kinds of acquirers usually pay more in an acquisition than private equity firms do, according to a study cited by Mark Hulbert in The New York Times. The study, conducted by finance professors and called “Why Do Private Acquirers Pay So Little Compared to Public Acquirers?”, found that, on average, target shareholders receive 55 percent more if a public company instead of a buyout shop (or shops) is paying the bill.
lead_paragraph: If you own shares in a takeover target, you might want to pin your hopes on a public company being the buyer. That is because these kinds of acquirers usually pay more in an acquisition than private equity firms do, according to a study cited by Mark Hulbert in The New York Times. The study, conducted by finance professors and called “Why Do Private Acquirers Pay So Little Compared to Public Acquirers?”, found that, on average, target shareholders receive 55 percent more if a public company instead of a buyout shop (or shops) is paying the bill.

headline.main: The Buyout Discount, or Why Private Equity Pays Less

abstract: Japan’s current account surplus widened to a record in March, as exports to Asia and Europe helped counter slower growth in shipments to the United States. The surplus expanded 36.9 percent, to 3.32 trillion yen ($28 billion) from a year earlier, the ministry of finance said. In other economic news, Japan’s machinery orders fell unexpectedly for a second month in March. Non-government orders excluding shipping and utilities dropped 4.5 percent from a month earlier after declining a revised 4.9 percent in February.

abstract: GRIDLOCK AHEAD? With 750 million domestic passengers expected to fly this year, “the air transportation system is stretched thin,” the Federal Aviation Administration said in a report. It called for increased financing for "major technology upgrades and capacity-improvement projects at major airports" to avoid what the agency said would be aviation “gridlock.” Last year, the F.A.A. said, airline delays were “the worst in history.” DELTA HELICOPTER SHUTTLE US Helicopter, which operates helicopter shuttles with 325 flights a week to Kennedy International and Newark airports and Bridgeport, Conn., is now flying into Delta Air Lines Terminal 3 at Kennedy, rather than American Airlines Terminal 9. One-way fares for the eight-minute trip from Manhattan to Kennedy or Newark start at $159. At Newark, the shuttles land next to Continental Airlines Terminal C.

abstract: Reuters Group and the Thomson Corporation said Tuesday that they had agreed to a $17.2 billion combination that will create one of the world’s largest financial news providers. The announcement came less than two weeks after the two companies said they were in talks about a possible merger. The deal is not without obstacles, however. Antitrust regulators, and especially those in the European Union, are likely to take a close look at the transaction and its effects on competition. An analyst in London told Bloomberg News there was a “75 percent chance” the deal would go through.
lead_paragraph: Reuters Group and the Thomson Corporation said Tuesday that they had agreed to a $17.2 billion combination that will create one of the world’s largest financial news providers. The announcement came less than two weeks after the two companies said they were in talks about a possible merger. The deal is not without obstacles, however. Antitrust regulators, and especially those in the European Union, are likely to take a close look at the transaction and its effects on competition. An analyst in London told Bloomberg News there was a “75 percent chance” the deal would go through.

headline.main: Thomson and Reuters Agree to $17 Billion Merger

abstract: Tyco International agreed on Tuesday to pay $2.98 billion to settle investors’ lawsuits accusing the company of artificially inflating revenue, a move that helps clear the way for the firm to split into three companies. The agreement will resolve securities-fraud suits alleging that the company overstated its income by more than $5 billion under its former chief executive, L. Dennis Kozlowski.

abstract: Evercore Partners said Tuesday that its net income fell 84 percent to $4.2 million in the first quarter. But after factoring in the effects of last year’s initial public offering and other accounting adjustments, Evercore’s profit more than doubled from a year earlier to $16 million, lifted by strength in its merger advisory business, the investment bank said.

abstract: Even as rumors swirl that Yahoo might be heading for some kind of deal with Microsoft, the Internet giant has picked a technology deal maker as its next chief financial officer. Yahoo announced Tuesday that it had hired Blake J. Jorgensen, a co-founder of the technology-focused investment bank Thomas Weisel Partners, as its finance chief. He will succeed Susan L. Decker, who took control of the company’s advertising operations in December amid mounting competition from its archrival Google.

abstract: As the business world continues to examine every nook and cranny of the $7.4 billion acquisition of Chrysler, many are wondering about the driving force behind the deal: Cerberus Capital Management. The hedge fund and private equity firm has many reputations, including that of hard-charging negotiator and behind-the-scenes operator, loath to step into the spotlight. Both qualities could be said to apply to Cerberus’s founder, Stephen A. Feinberg, a Drexel Burnham Lambert alumnus, Princeton graduate and former Army paratrooper.
lead_paragraph: As the business world continues to examine every nook and cranny of the $7.4 billion acquisition of Chrysler, many are wondering about the driving force behind the deal: Cerberus Capital Management. The hedge fund and private equity firm has many reputations, including that of hard-charging negotiator and behind-the-scenes operator, loath to step into the spotlight. Both qualities could be said to apply to Cerberus’s founder, Stephen A. Feinberg, a Drexel Burnham Lambert alumnus, Princeton graduate and former Army paratrooper.

headline.main: From Behind the Scenes to Behind the Wheel

abstract: Given his repeated entreaties to the Bancroft family and his recent promises to shield The Wall Street Journal’s newsroom from his own meddling as owner, News Corporation chief Rupert Murdoch seems almost desperate to buy Dow Jones. He has written three letters to pitch his proposal and offered to hold tetes-a-tetes with the family members, who have a controlling stake in the company — all this on top of the rich premium contained in his $5 billion offer. But there is something else the media mogul can do, according to Breakingviews: Throw more bags of money at the Bancrofts, while leaving common shareholders with his current offer.
lead_paragraph: Given his repeated entreaties to the Bancroft family and his recent promises to shield The Wall Street Journal’s newsroom from his own meddling as owner, News Corporation chief Rupert Murdoch seems almost desperate to buy Dow Jones. He has written three letters to pitch his proposal and offered to hold tetes-a-tetes with the family members, who have a controlling stake in the company — all this on top of the rich premium contained in his $5 billion offer. But there is something else the media mogul can do, according to Breakingviews: Throw more bags of money at the Bancrofts, while leaving common shareholders with his current offer.

headline.main: Is the Key to Dow Jones in the Bancrofts’ Wallets?

abstract: Media deals may be all the rage these days, but some analysts are seeing fodder for potential takeovers in the software industry as well. Kirk Materne and Daniel Cummins of Bank of America ran the numbers and found eight big software companies with low-enough stock values to make them attractive takeover candidates, even if the acquirer shelled out a 25 percent premium to the current price. The analysts emphasized they had no reason to believe a specific deal for any of them was in the works, but they also argued that consolidation in the software industry looked “inevitable.”

The analysts emphasized they had no reason to believe a specific deal for any of them was in the works, but they also argued that consolidation in the software industry looked “inevitable.”

abstract: When Peter G. Peterson retires at the end of next year, he will be able to relax in some luxurious digs. The co-founder of private equity giant Blackstone Group has just shelled out $37.5 million to buy media mogul David Geffen’s 12-room duplex penthouse on Fifth Avenue in New York, city records show. The New York Observer, which noted the deal on its real estate blog, points out that Mr. Geffen bought the apartment last year for $31.5 million. That’s a 19 percent markup in a year — a respectable return even in private equity circles.

abstract: Limited Brands announced Tuesday that it was selling its 67 percent stake in Express for $548 million and that it would weigh a sale of its Limited Stores business. With the sale to the private equity firm Golden Gate Capital, the company will focus on its Victoria’s Secret and Bath & Body Works businesses, among others. The streamlining plan was announced as the company also lowered its guidance for the first quarter. In afternoon trading, Limited shares were down 4 percent.

abstract: The Iamgold Corporation, a Canadian gold producer, said first-quarter net income fell 43 percent on losses from derivatives and higher mining costs. Profit declined to $11.3 million from $19.9 million a year ago, Iamgold said. Profit per share fell to 4 cents, from 13 cents, as Iamgold issued shares to pay for its acquisition last November of its rival Cambior for $1.1 billion. Sales more than tripled, to $146.4 million. Iamgold’s cash cost of producing an ounce of gold rose 54 percent, to $416, from a year ago on higher labor and fuel costs.

lead_paragraph: THE day when doctors treated patients at home disappeared decades ago in most of America as house calls gave way to more cost-effective office visits. abstract: Vivendi said its first-quarter profit rose 32 percent, spurred by demand for its World of Warcraft video game and subscriber growth at the pay-television unit. Net income rose to 932 million euros ($1.27 billion) from 707 million euros ($957.5 million) a year earlier, Vivendi said. First-quarter sales rose 5.3 percent, to 5.02 billion euros ($6.8 billion) from 4.77 billion euros ($6.47 billion) a year earlier. Profit at Vivendi Games surged to 107 million euros ($145 million) from 23 million euros ($31.1 million) a year earlier. The unit sold almost 2.4 million copies of the expansion pack to World of Warcraft the first day it went on sale in January. Profit at the pay-television unit Canal Plus jumped fivefold, to 164 million euros ($222.1 million). Profit at the mobile phone unit SFR, Vivendi’s largest business, slipped 3.5 percent, to 643 million euros ($871 million). Profit was down at the Universal Music Group, hurt by falling CD sales.

abstract: HeidelbergCement, a German concrete maker, has agreed to buy Hanson, a British supplier of building materials, for £7.85 billion ($16 billion). HeidelbergCement will pay £11 ($21.80) a share for Hanson, a premium of 29 percent over Hanson’s share price on May 2 when HeidelbergCement first said it might bid. With the purchase, HeidelbergCement will increase its revenue by two-thirds, expanding in the United States and bolstering output of aggregates, pipes and bricks. “The companies are a perfect fit and overlaps are minimal,” HeidelbergCement’s chief executive, Bernd Scheifele, above, said in a conference call with analysts. “Hanson strengthens our operations in the U.S., U.K. and Europe and adds a business in Australia.” Hanson has 26,000 workers in 14 nations and derives half its sales from North America.

abstract: What has the recent run of private equity megadeals meant for the United States economy, the middle class and income inequality? It’s hard to say for sure — at least that was the sense we got from watching the witnesses who testified Wednesday before the House Financial Services Committee. Still, that didn’t stop both lawmakers and some of the witnesses from offering their opinions on the matter, which has come into focus as labor organizations have raised questions about buyout funds, which acquire public companies in hopes of selling them after an operational or financial overhaul, and whether they are good for United States workers.

abstract: Yet again, carried interest is at the center of controversy. The carry, as it is called, is essentially the portion — usually 20 percent — of private equity funds’ investment profits that flow to the funds’ managers as a kind of performance fee. Some people, including lawmakers and labor groups, have recently questioned whether the carry deserves to be taxed at the lower capital gains rate (as it usually is) or whether it should be taxed as ordinary income (which the private equity industry naturally thinks is an awful idea).
lead_paragraph: Yet again, carried interest is at the center of controversy. The carry, as it is called, is essentially the portion — usually 20 percent — of private equity funds’ investment profits that flow to the funds’ managers as a kind of performance fee. Some people, including lawmakers and labor groups, have recently questioned whether the carry deserves to be taxed at the lower capital gains rate (as it usually is) or whether it should be taxed as ordinary income (which the private equity industry naturally thinks is an awful idea).

headline.main: Why Blackstone Is, or Isn’t, an Investment Company

abstract: Cerberus Capital Management may be turning its attention from an auto giant to a telephone behemoth. The firm, which this week agreed to buy Chrysler, is considering making an offer to buy BCE, creating the potential for a three-way bidding battle for the parent of Bell Canada, The Globe and Mail reported. But the private equity firm would need to assemble Canadian partners to get around foreign ownership limits. And BCE is already in talks with a group led by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board about a possible $45 billion buyout. Meanwhile, a consortium led by Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan is also circling.

abstract: Alliance Data Systems, which administers credit card programs for major retailers, said Thursday it agreed to be acquired by Blackstone Group in a deal it valued at $7.8 billion, including assumed debt. Blackstone will pay $81.75 in cash for each share of Alliance Data, about 30 percent more than the stock’s Wednesday closing price. If approved by shareholders, the buyout would end Alliance’s six-year run as a public company and put it back in the hands of a private equity firm. Alliance was formed in 1996 by Welsh Carson Anderson Stowe, which combined two businesses it bought from J.C. Penney and Limited Brands.

The company said it expected to raise about $75.2 million in the stock sale.

abstract: A week after confirming that it hired an investment bank to explore “strategic alternatives,” 24/7 Real Media has decided that a sale is the way to go. The company, which provides online marketing services, said it agreed to be bought by advertising and marketing firm WPP Group for $11.75 per share in cash, or about $649 million net of cash acquired. The sale of 24/7 is just the latest in a string of deals involving online advertising companies: Google recently bought DoubleClick for $3.1 billion, and Yahoo  paid $680 million for the part of Right Media that it didn’t already own.

abstract: Last year’s record for global deal activity could be a short-lived one, if the predictions of a group of deal makers surveyed by Mergermarket turn out to be correct. Many of the bankers, buyout professionals and chief executives said in the survey that they expect to see continued strength in 2007 in both mergers and acquisitions and leveraged buyouts. In fact, more than half of the respondents are looking for another increase this year in M&A among large-cap companies. Most of the rest believe the level of deals will remain about the same as last year’s. Just four percent said they expect deal activity to recede.

Most of the rest believe the level of deals will remain about the same as last year’s. Just four percent said they expect deal activity to recede.

abstract: Bank of Montreal, stung by a huge loss from natural gas trading, said the debacle would cost at least 50 percent more than originally forecast and started an investigation into potential irregularities. Bank of Montreal said it would record pretax losses of 680 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from the trades, compared with an April 27 forecast of 350 million to 450 million Canadian dollars. Two New York-based bankers involved in the trades have left the firm. The bank said the losses were bigger than it originally forecast after it adopted a different pricing model to better assess the value of its natural gas options contracts. The revision also reflects “increased concerns” about the reliability of quotes from its main broker.

abstract: Margaret A. Jackson, the chairwoman of Qantas Airways, who was one of the proponents of a failed attempt to take the airline private, will retire, a company spokesman said. Ms. Jackson, 54, told the board that she would not seek re-election at the airline’s annual meeting in October, said Simon Rushton, a spokesman for Qantas. The buyout attempt, led by the Macquarie Bank and TPG, collapsed two weeks ago when investors rejected a cash offer of 5.45 Australian dollars a share as too low. The buyout group says it will not make another bid. Ms. Jackson joined the board in July 1992 and was appointed chairwoman in August 2000.

abstract: Mexico’s economy grew in the first quarter at its slowest rate in more than a year as construction fell and automobile output declined on slumping demand in the United States. Gross domestic product grew 2.6 percent from a year earlier, the government reported. A growth rate of less than 3 percent suggests Mexico is failing to reduce dependence on exports to the United States, the destination for about 80 percent of the country’s sales abroad. Last year’s 4.8 percent growth, Mexico’s fastest in six years, was driven by strong United States demand, while the weakening economy last quarter similarly tracked the United States slowdown.

abstract: Clear Channel Communications is hoping that an extra 20 cents a share, plus the option to own a piece of the company, will finally clear the way for its controversial buyout to go through. The radio broadcasting giant said Friday that it had agreed to amend the terms of the buyout to include $39.20 in cash for each Clear Channel share, up from $39, and a provision allowing shareholders to take stock in the post-takeover company instead of cash. The “stub equity,” as the stock portion is commonly called, would be limited to 30 percent of Clear Channel’s equity and would not be listed on any exchange, Clear Channel said in a press release.
lead_paragraph: Clear Channel Communications is hoping that an extra 20 cents a share, plus the option to own a piece of the company, will finally clear the way for its controversial buyout to go through. The radio broadcasting giant said Friday that it had agreed to amend the terms of the buyout to include $39.20 in cash for each Clear Channel share, up from $39, and a provision allowing shareholders to take stock in the post-takeover company instead of cash. The “stub equity,” as the stock portion is commonly called, would be limited to 30 percent of Clear Channel’s equity and would not be listed on any exchange, Clear Channel said in a press release.

headline.main: Clear Channel Accepts Revised Takeover Bid

abstract: Whether it was because of sheer luck or an inside tip, options traders made some big bets on aQuantive on Thursday — just in time to cash in on the company’s $6 billion deal to be acquired by Microsoft. Trading in aQuantive’s options has been active for weeks, driven in part by the rampant takeover speculation surrounding many independent Web advertising firms since Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick in mid-April. But according to Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, activity in aQuantive’s call options went through the roof on Thursday, with a volume of 9,363 contracts, or more than five times the average volume on the previous five days.
lead_paragraph: Whether it was because of sheer luck or an inside tip, options traders made some big bets on aQuantive on Thursday — just in time to cash in on the company’s $6 billion deal to be acquired by Microsoft. Trading in aQuantive’s options has been active for weeks, driven in part by the rampant takeover speculation surrounding many independent Web advertising firms since Google‘s $3.1 billion deal for DoubleClick in mid-April. But according to Jon Najarian, co-founder of OptionMonster, activity in aQuantive’s call options went through the roof on Thursday, with a volume of 9,363 contracts, or more than five times the average volume on the previous five days.

headline.main: Before the aQuantive Deal, Lots of Well-Timed Trades

abstract: Microsoft had about $28 billion in cash and short-term investment on March 31, an amount the CIA World Factbook tells us is more than twice the gross domestic product of Iceland. But despite its riches, the software giant has shied away from large acquisitions, especially in the past five years or so. That is part of the reason Friday’s $6 billion cash bid for online advertising company aQuantive was so surprising. (The 85 percent premium it agreed to pay was something of a shock as well.)

The Chinese delegation will be led by Vice Premier Wu Yi, right.

headline.main: Looking Ahead

abstract: Europe’s largest engineering company named Peter Löscher as its new chief executive.

lead_paragraph: MUNICH, May 20 (Bloomberg News) — Siemens, Europe’s largest engineering company, named Peter Löscher, an executive of the American drug maker Merck, as its chief executive, to succeed Klaus Kleinfeld, who resigned after less than three years because of a bribery investigation on his watch.

abstract: Alltel‘s agreement to go private in a $27.5 billion deal — the largest leveraged buyout ever in the telecommunications industry — is not sitting well with some of the other private equity firms who lined up to bid for the wireless phone company. The deal to be acquired by a consortium including the Texas Pacific Group and a unit of Goldman Sachs effectively short-circuits the auction process, in which other groups, such as the Blackstone Group with Providence Equity Partners, and the Carlyle Group with Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, had hoped to participate.

S.E.C. Chairman Christopher Cox told Barron’s that he and four other commissioners are briefed each month by the CIA, offering the S.E.C. a “somewhat sharper focus” to an “underworld of murky, illegal dealings that threaten the world capital markets.”

abstract: The environment for today’s entrepreneurs is far different in a number of ways from the boom of the late ’90s, Steven Levy noted this week in Newsweek. It is “dramatically cheaper to start a company now,” he wrote, so it is substantially easier to build a business, sometimes without needing venture capital. “Software tools, which used to cost hundreds of thousands, are now largely free,” while computer equipment and bandwidth are much less expensive.

abstract: Corporate takeovers helped spur the Dow Jones industrial average to its 24th record close this year on Friday, even as the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index came within striking distance of its record high. The latest takeover news, including deals involving marquee names like General Electric and Microsoft, signaled that the enormous amount of liquidity that has lubricated global stock markets in recent months is still in good supply. “The M.& A. activity and earnings seem to be holding up better than expected. I think you’re going to see more of this,” Bill Dwyer, chief investment officer at MTB Investment Advisors, told The Associated Press.

abstract: A company based in New Jersey that provides training and treatment programs to prison inmates is announcing today that it has bought a similar Massachusetts company, creating one of the largest correctional services companies in the country. abstract: Federal prosecutors have asked a judge to immediately freeze the assets of Joseph Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications International, who was convicted last month of making $52 million from insider trading. abstract: Blackstone Group pulled back the veil a little further on its closely watched initial public offering on Monday, as it filed an amended prospectus with regulators. The major addition was the terms of its planned $3 billion investment from China, but the financial aspects of the offering were fleshed out as well. The private equity giant said that it planned to offer 133.3 million units at a price of $29 to $31 each and was giving underwriters the option of selling 20 million more. At the maximum, the I.P.O. could raise a whopping $4.75 billion (an amount that doesn’t include the $3 billion infusion from China’s investment arm).

abstract: Kirk Kerkorian said this afternoon that he planned “to pursue strategic alternatives” for his controlling stake in MGM Mirage, the giant hotel and casino company. Mr. Kerkorian also said that he planned to enter talks to buy Bellagio Hotel and Casino and City Center properties from MGM Mirage. The brief, three-sentence statement from Mr. Kerkorian’s holding company, Tracinda, has caused a lot of head scratching at DealBook about his intentions, but that hasn’t stopped investors from bidding up shares of MGM Mirage by more than $9, or 15 percent, in after-hours trading. It is unclear whether he plans to put his controlling stake up for sale or whether he is considering buying up the outstanding public shares, either himself or with a partner.
lead_paragraph: Kirk Kerkorian said this afternoon that he planned “to pursue strategic alternatives” for his controlling stake in MGM Mirage, the giant hotel and casino company. Mr. Kerkorian also said that he planned to enter talks to buy Bellagio Hotel and Casino and City Center properties from MGM Mirage. The brief, three-sentence statement from Mr. Kerkorian’s holding company, Tracinda, has caused a lot of head scratching at DealBook about his intentions, but that hasn’t stopped investors from bidding up shares of MGM Mirage by more than $9, or 15 percent, in after-hours trading. It is unclear whether he plans to put his controlling stake up for sale or whether he is considering buying up the outstanding public shares, either himself or with a partner.

headline.main: Has Kerkorian Put MGM Mirage in Play?

abstract: Monday was a big deal for dealmaking. It may have been an even bigger day for Citigroup. Citi’s investment bank had a role in all the big headline deals of the day — more than $80 billion worth — which propelled it into first place, ahead of Goldman Sachs, in the worldwide merger advisory league tables compiled by Thomson Financial. Among the recent deals in which Citi had a hand were Alltel‘s $27.5 billion sale to TPG and Goldman Sachs; General Electric‘s sale of its plastics division to Saudi Basic Industries for $11.6 billion; EMI‘s 3.5 billion pound sale to Terra Firma; UniCredit‘s $29 billion acquisition of Capitalia; Banca Popolare di Milano‘s purchase of Banca Popolare dell’Emilia Romagna for $7.6 billion.
lead_paragraph: Monday was a big deal for dealmaking. It may have been an even bigger day for Citigroup. Citi’s investment bank had a role in all the big headline deals of the day — more than $80 billion worth — which propelled it into first place, ahead of Goldman Sachs, in the worldwide merger advisory league tables compiled by Thomson Financial. Among the recent deals in which Citi had a hand were Alltel‘s $27.5 billion sale to TPG and Goldman Sachs; General Electric‘s sale of its plastics division to Saudi Basic Industries for $11.6 billion; EMI‘s 3.5 billion pound sale to Terra Firma; UniCredit‘s $29 billion acquisition of Capitalia; Banca Popolare di Milano‘s purchase of Banca Popolare dell’Emilia Romagna for $7.6 billion.

headline.main: A Good Day at the Office for Citigroup

abstract: MAJOR AIRPORT INVESTMENT URGED Airports need to spend more than $87 billion for infrastructure and other improvements by 2011 to accommodate increasing passenger and air-cargo demand, according to a study by the Airports Council International North America. “Anyone traveling by air today knows that aviation is already stretched to the breaking point,” said Greg Principato, president of the council. In a statement, the group said that “2007 is stacking up to be similar to and in some instances worse than 2000, a year which until now had the dubious distinction of being the peak year for air-travel delays.” Most airport improvement projects — for runways, terminals, gates and the like — are paid for by the so-called passenger facility charge added to the price of airline tickets. That charge has been capped by Congress at $4.50 since 2000, but the council said Congress should increase the cap.
snippet: MAJOR AIRPORT INVESTMENT URGED Airports need to spend more than $87 billion for infrastructure and other improvements by 2011 to accommodate increasing passenger and air-cargo demand, according to a study by the Airports Council International Nort...

In a statement, the group said that “2007 is stacking up to be similar to and in some instances worse than 2000, a year which until now had the dubious distinction of being the peak year for air-travel delays.” Most airport improvement projects — for runways, terminals, gates and the like — are paid for by the so-called passenger facility charge added to the price of airline tickets. That charge has been capped by Congress at $4.50 since 2000, but the council said Congress should increase the cap.

abstract: Lately I’ve been noticing those who swim against the tide of self-employment.

Put it that way and it doesn’t sound so bad after all, does it?

abstract: Two senior partners of J.W. Childs Associates are leaving the Boston private equity shop to start their own firm, according to The Deal.com. Dana Schmaltz and Ted Yun each joined J.W. Mr. Schmaltz, who now serves as president, joined in 1997, while Mr. Yun, a partner and chairman of the investment committee, came on board in 1999. Their departure is expected at the beginning of June, sources told The Deal.

abstract: Corporate boards are nearly three times as likely to push out failing chief executives than they were a decade ago, a new study examining turnover among top executives has found. Nearly one of three chief executives who departed last year were either fired or forced out for performance-related reasons, according to the analysis by the global management consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton. That compared with roughly one in seven departing executives ousted in 1996.
lead_paragraph: Corporate boards are nearly three times as likely to push out failing chief executives than they were a decade ago, a new study examining turnover among top executives has found. Nearly one of three chief executives who departed last year were either fired or forced out for performance-related reasons, according to the analysis by the global management consulting firm Booz Allen Hamilton. That compared with roughly one in seven departing executives ousted in 1996.

headline.main: Boards More Likely to Oust Failing Chiefs

abstract: Paul Weiss Rifkind Wharton & Garrison said it hired Jennifer A. Spiegel as counsel in its corporate department. Ms. Spiegel, previously of Debevoise & Plimpton, will be part of Paul Weiss’s investment funds group, which advises on fund organization, registration and compliance as well as the buying and selling of investment advisers. The investment funds group has grown to more than 20 lawyers, Paul Weiss said.

abstract: In a deal that has been rumored for some time, Electronic Arts announced Monday that it is investing about $167 million to buy a 15 percent stake in The9, a Chinese video game company. As part of the deal, The9 acquired an exclusive license to publish E.A.’s “FIFA Online” soccer game in China.

abstract: When an activist hedge fund makes headlines, it’s generally raising a ruckus over a company’s poor management decisions. MMI Investments, Acxiom’s second-largest shareholder, is objecting to the sale of the company to Acxiom’s largest shareholder, ValueAct, and the private equity firm Silver Lake.

abstract: Could a muni bond court rulilng also end discriminatory property taxes?
snippet: Could a muni bond court rulilng also end discriminatory property taxes?
lead_paragraph: Taxing the other guy — not the locals who can vote in local elections –has obvious appeal to politicians. It helps to explain the widespread use of discriminatory taxing of municipal bond interest. If you live in New York, bonds issued by that state, and its cities and other agencies, are not subject to state income tax. But those issued by other states are.

headline.main: State Tax Discrimination

abstract: Whatever happens at MGM Mirage, it looks like Kirk Kerkorian will walk away a winner. That is what several analysts suggested Tuesday as they pondered Monday’s short but highly suggestive announcement by Tracinda, Mr. Kerkorian’s investment vehicle, that it would begin negotiating to buy two Las Vegas properties from MGM Mirage and consider alternatives for its majority stake in MGM. Mr. Kerkorian has already hit the jackpot, at least on paper. Shares of MGM Mirage surged 26 percent in early trading Tuesday to $79.32. As a result, the value of Mr. Kerkorian’s 56 percent stake in the casino company grew by $2.6 billion overnight.

abstract: Fremont General, a California lender stung by recent weakness in the subprime mortgage market, said Tuesday it had agreed to sell its commercial lending business to iStar Financial for about $1.9 billion, leaving the company to focus on its retail operations. Fremont also said that it would sell a minority stake in the entire company to an investor group led by Gerald Ford, the former chief executive of Golden State Bancorp, who will become its new chairman.
lead_paragraph: Fremont General, a California lender stung by recent weakness in the subprime mortgage market, said Tuesday it had agreed to sell its commercial lending business to iStar Financial for about $1.9 billion, leaving the company to focus on its retail operations. abstract: Speaking words that are bound to disappoint a few investment bankers, Jeffrey Immelt, the chief executive of General Electric, said the giant conglomerate is likely to avoid big deals for the time being. Interviewed by The Financial Times after the announcement that a Saudi Arabian company would buy G.E.’s plastics business for about $11.6 billion, Mr. Immelt said, “I like the company in the current position. We will remain tough-minded about opportunities, but the sale of the plastics business is consistent with our strategy.” Instead, he indicated that the company will look to return excess cash to shareholders and expand its current lines of business.

We will remain tough-minded about opportunities, but the sale of the plastics business is consistent with our strategy.” Instead, he indicated that the company will look to return excess cash to shareholders and expand its current lines of business.

headline.main: Is Jeff Immelt Done With Deal Making?

abstract: Presidential candidates in both parties have been wooing the Wall Street set in a big way this election season. Last Friday, it was the turn of Democrat Barack Obama, who touched down in Greenwich, Conn., the unofficial hub of the hedge fund set, for a pair of fundraisers. The first was co-hosted by George Soros, the financier and former hedge fund manager, and Paul Tudor Jones, who runs the giant hedge fund Tudor Investment Corporation. That event, held in Mr. Jones’s $25 million waterfront mansion — which Vanity Fair’s Nina Munk has described as a “a cross between Tara and a national monument” — collected $2,300 from each of the approximately 300 attendees, the Greenwich Time reported.

abstract: The explosive growth of private equity deals is a well-documented trend by now, but some new numbers from Thomson Financial underscore just how enormous the volume of buyouts has become. Consider this: So far this year, the volume of global announced deals involving private equity firms is $447 billion, more than double the volume from the same period in 2006 — a year that was no slouch was far as buyouts were concerned. In the United States, the rise has been even sharper. At $281 billion, U.S. private equity deals have more than tripled from a year ago, boosted by the recent buyouts of Alltel, First Data and others.

abstract: In the latest twist in a legal battle that’s starting to resemble a corkscrew, Aaron Charney, the former Sullivan & Cromwell associate who has sued the law firm alleging gay bias, added several charges to his complaint Monday. To his initial allegations of discrimination based on sexual orientation, Mr. Charney has added claims of emotional distress and conspiracy, according to the New York Law Journal. Before his suit caused a stir in legal circles, Mr. Charney had worked in the mergers and acquisitions group at one of the leading firms that advises in such deals.

abstract: Nortel Networks said it would pay 1 million Canadian dollars ($921,000) as part of a settlement with the Ontario Securities Commission. The payment is not a fine. The company called it a contribution toward the cost of the commission’s investigation into accounting irregularities at the company from 2000 to 2003. Nortel, the communications equipment maker, acknowledged in the agreement that its senior executives had improperly altered accounting policies and provisions to improve the company’s apparent financial performance. Under the agreement, the company must give the commission special quarterly and annual reports on efforts to improve its accounting controls. Nortel fired its chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, and two other executives over the bookkeeping issues in 2004. The former executives face separate charges by the Ontario regulator. The Securities and Exchange Commission has also charged the three as well as other former Nortel employees. Law enforcement officials in both Canada and the United States are also investigating the company.

abstract: Viacom and an Indian media company, the TV18 Group, said they would jointly create Viacom-18, a television, film and digital media company. Viacom-18 will start a Hindi-language entertainment channel later this year, and Viacom’s MTV Networks, which is already present in India, will become part of the joint venture. Viacom’s movie studios, DreamWorks and Paramount Pictures, will look for opportunities in India over the next few months, Viacom said. "India is one of Viacom’s priority markets for expansion internationally," Philippe P. Dauman, above, the president and chief executive of Viacom, said during a news conference in Mumbai.

abstract: German investor confidence rose to an 11-month high in May as company profits surged and economists raised their forecasts for growth this year. The Center for European Economic Research in Mannheim said its index of investor and analyst expectations increased to 24, the highest since June, from 16.5 in April. The center, known by the German acronym ZEW, said a gauge of investors’ assessment of the current situation rose to a record 88 from 76.9 last month.

abstract: In what may be a sign of the times, oil has trumped hedge funds in New York’s contest for real-estate bragging rights. The New York Times, picking up on a story on The New York Observer’s blog, reported Wednesday that an unnamed “London-based businessman in the oil business” has agreed to pay $56 million for a triplex penthouse condominium at New York’s Plaza Hotel. If the deal closes, it is likely to be the most expensive sale ever of an apartment in Manhattan. It would also break the record set by Daniel Loeb, the head of the hedge fund Third Point Capital, who is known for his exquisitely barbed letters to corporate managers.

abstract: Illinois Tool Works makes everything from self-drilling screws to commercial meat slicers. But is the 95-year-old industrial conglomerate interested in making a deal? abstract: The Bank of Montreal said second-quarter profit rose 3 percent as higher fees from mutual funds and stock sales offset a big loss in commodities trading. Net income climbed to 671 million Canadian dollars ($618 million) from 651 million Canadian dollars a year earlier, the bank said. Record mutual fund sales and rising demand for loans contributed to a 24 percent increase in consumer banking profit, countering the commodities losses, which were related to natural gas trading. The bank said on May 17 that it would report a pretax trading loss of 680 million Canadian dollars. Bank of Montreal said profit was 1.31 Canadian dollars a share excluding the trading loss and other one-time items, an increase of 3.1 percent from a year ago. Revenue in the quarter, which ended April 30, rose 2.7 percent, to 2.57 billion Canadian dollars from 2.5 billion Canadian dollars.

abstract: Export growth slowed in April as shipments to the United States fell for the first time in more than two years. Exports overall grew 8.3 percent, slowing from 10.3 percent growth in March, the Ministry of Finance said in a report. Shipments to the United States fell 4.8 percent, after growing 2.4 percent the previous month. The slowest growth in four years in the United States, destination of a fifth of Japanese exports, led to reduced demand for automobiles and electronics. Japan’s trade surplus in April rose 51.8 percent, to 926.7 billion yen ($7.6 billion).

abstract: A leading diabetes doctor sent the Food and Drug Administration a letter seven years ago that warned of the heart risks of the drug Avandia.
snippet: A leading diabetes doctor sent the Food and Drug Administration a letter seven years ago that warned of the heart risks of the drug Avandia.
lead_paragraph: A leading diabetes doctor sent the Food and Drug Administration a letter seven years ago that warned of the heart risks of the drug Avandia. And in the next year, the F.D.A. reprimanded the drug’s maker for playing down safety concerns, according to documents from 2000 and 2001.

headline.main: Years Ago, Agency Was Warned of a Drug’s Risks
headline.print_headline: Years Ago, Agency Was Warned of a Drug’s Risks

abstract: The aluminum producer Alcoa said in a statement that it would continue to pursue its $27.4 billion cash and stock bid for a rival, Alcan, despite the Canadian company’s rejection of the offer. But Alcoa’s chairman and chief executive, Alain J. P. Belda, said that the company would not enhance the proposal, which Alcan called inadequate. “We have studied Alcan’s response and have not seen anything that would lead us to re-evaluate our offer,” Mr. Belda said. He also rejected suggestions by Alcan that Alcoa would have difficulty obtaining antitrust approval for the merger and urged Alcan’s board to resume its examination of the bid.

He also rejected suggestions by Alcan that Alcoa would have difficulty obtaining antitrust approval for the merger and urged Alcan’s board to resume its examination of the bid.

abstract: The European Parliament voted to impose retail price caps on roaming charges, fees that mobile phone consumers pay when making or receiving calls outside of their home calling zones. The European Council of Ministers, which has already endorsed the plan, is scheduled to approve the price caps formally June 7. As early as August, the charges will be limited to 0.49 euro (66 cents) a minute for outgoing calls and 0.24 euro for incoming calls, excluding tax.

The European Council of Ministers, which has already endorsed the plan, is scheduled to approve the price caps formally June 7. As early as August, the charges will be limited to 0.49 euro (66 cents) a minute for outgoing calls and 0.24 euro for incoming calls, excluding tax.

headline.main: Limits on Roaming Charges

abstract: Check balances, transfer money and even pay bills on a handset.

Or perhaps you’re standing in the checkout line of a store, poised to make a debit card payment, but you can’t remember if you have enough money in your account to avoid expensive overdraft charges.

abstract: BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, the largest communications company in Canada, said that a group led by Cerberus Capital had joined the bidding for the company. While the other investors were not identified, they will be vital to any deal because Canadian law bans foreign control of telephone companies. Three groups are now vying to take BCE private. BCE’s largest shareholder, the Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan, has allied itself with other institutional investors for a possible bid. The Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts have formed a rival group that may make a bid potentially worth about $45 billion.

He was 85. A resident of Lafayette, Colo., Mr. Peters had lived for many years in Guilford, Conn.
