abstract: Scratch is like a multimedia sandbox, where children 8 and up are welcomed as media producers.
snippet: Scratch is like a multimedia sandbox, where children 8 and up are welcomed as media producers.
lead_paragraph: Scratch is a creativity tool from the M.I.T. Media Lab that turns abstract programming concepts like recursion into snap-together puzzle pieces. It is like a multimedia sandbox, where children 8 and up are welcomed as media producers, following the same philosophical blueprint that inspired software projects like Logo and Squeak.

headline.main: A Programming Language Like Playing With Blocks
headline.print_headline: A Programming Language Like Playing With Blocks

abstract: Hewlett-Packard, the computer maker, put to rest one aspect of the spying scandal that rocked its boardroom last year as it settled an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into how it disclosed the resignation of Thomas Perkins, a prominent venture capitalist, from its board. Though the settlement came with no financial or other penalty, the S.E.C. said it found that Hewlett-Packard “failed to disclose the reasons for his resignation as required by federal securities laws” after Mr. Perkins left the board in May 2006 because of his objection to an internal investigation into leaks to the press. Hewlett consented to an order that it stop violations of disclosure provisions, but did not admit or deny the commission’s findings.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard, the computer maker, put to rest one aspect of the spying scandal that rocked its boardroom last year as it settled an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission into how it disclosed the resignation of Thomas Perkins, a prominent venture capitalist, from its board. Though the settlement came with no financial or other penalty, the S.E.C. said it found that Hewlett-Packard “failed to disclose the reasons for his resignation as required by federal securities laws” after Mr. Perkins left the board in May 2006 because of his objection to an internal investigation into leaks to the press. Hewlett consented to an order that it stop violations of disclosure provisions, but did not admit or deny the commission’s findings.

headline.main: H.P.’s Disclosure About Resignation Fell Short, S.E.C. Says

abstract: Amazon.com announced Wednesday its acquisition of an audio-book publisher, Brilliance Audio, in a move to tighten its tie with book publishers and expand the number of audio-book titles it sells. Amazon is seeking to expand beyond offering only best-sellers under an audio-book format. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.

abstract: The British government is considering selling commercial broadcaster Channel 4 to raise up to 1 billion pounds after Gordon Brown becomes prime minister, according to The Times of London. Treasury officials in Britain are weighing economic and political arguments for privatizing the government-owned channel, even though the Labor party manifesto is committed to keeping Channel 4 in public ownership, according to the report.
lead_paragraph: The British government is considering selling commercial broadcaster Channel 4 to raise up to 1 billion pounds after Gordon Brown becomes prime minister, according to The Times of London. Treasury officials in Britain are weighing economic and political arguments for privatizing the government-owned channel, even though the Labor party manifesto is committed to keeping Channel 4 in public ownership, according to the report.

headline.main: Britain Said to Consider Sale of Channel 4

abstract: The fight between Daniel Loeb’s hedge fund, Third Point, and PDL BioPharma, a drug development company, escalated this week as Mr. Loeb, known for his poison-pen letters to some of the companies in which he invests, released a letter to “unconflicted directors of PDL”, urging them to oust L. Patrick Gage, the company’s chairman.

abstract: General Motors has put up a 49 percent stake in its former financial arm as collateral for a $4.1 billion revolving line of credit, the company said late Wednesday. It also announced plans to replace $1.1 billion in convertible securities with new ones with a later maturity date. After the announcement, Fitch Ratings cut its debt rating for G.M. deeper into junk territory, citing increased leverage from new financing efforts. Separately, G.M. said it received a new request from the Securities and Exchange Commission for information about its accounting practices.
lead_paragraph: General Motors has put up a 49 percent stake in its former financial arm as collateral for a $4.1 billion revolving line of credit, the company said late Wednesday. It also announced plans to replace $1.1 billion in convertible securities with new ones with a later maturity date. After the announcement, Fitch Ratings cut its debt rating for G.M. deeper into junk territory, citing increased leverage from new financing efforts. Separately, G.M. said it received a new request from the Securities and Exchange Commission for information about its accounting practices.

headline.main: G.M. Pledges GMAC Stake for $4 Billion Credit Line

abstract: A former secretary at Coca-Cola was sentenced Wednesday to eight years in prison for conspiring to steal trade secrets from the company, as her tearful plea for mercy failed to sway a federal judge. Judge J. Owen Forrester of Federal District Court told the former secretary, Joya Williams, 42, that he was giving her a longer sentence than recommended by federal prosecutors and sentencing guidelines because “this is the kind of offense that cannot be tolerated in our society.”
lead_paragraph: A former secretary at Coca-Cola was sentenced Wednesday to eight years in prison for conspiring to steal trade secrets from the company, as her tearful plea for mercy failed to sway a federal judge. Judge J. Owen Forrester of Federal District Court told the former secretary, Joya Williams, 42, that he was giving her a longer sentence than recommended by federal prosecutors and sentencing guidelines because “this is the kind of offense that cannot be tolerated in our society.”

headline.main: 8-Year Sentence in Coca-Cola Secrets Case

abstract: The British government ordered the country’s competition regulator Thursday to hold a full inquiry into British Sky Broadcasting‘s purchase of a stake in broadcaster ITV. The Associated Press noted that the order for the Competition Commission investigation marks the first major test of the influence held over the British media by Rupert Murdoch, BSkyB’s chairman and largest stockholder.

abstract: Bisys Group, a financial-services provider that recently agreed to be acquired by Citigroup, said Wednesday it would pay $25 million to settle regulators’ accusations that it had violated financial reporting rules to inflate earnings by $180 million over three years. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlement with Bisys, which was consistent with a tentative agreement that the company and the agency’s enforcement staff negotiated in November.
lead_paragraph: Bisys Group, a financial-services provider that recently agreed to be acquired by Citigroup, said Wednesday it would pay $25 million to settle regulators’ accusations that it had violated financial reporting rules to inflate earnings by $180 million over three years. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced the settlement with Bisys, which was consistent with a tentative agreement that the company and the agency’s enforcement staff negotiated in November.

headline.main: Bisys Settles With S.E.C. for $25 Million

abstract: Qwest Communications International‘s shareholders have rejected three proposals that would have given them more influence in decisions about executive compensation. At the company’s annual meeting Tuesday, its chief executive, Richard C. Notebaert, was peppered with questions about salaries and bonuses, including his own, and cuts or caps in benefits for about 49,000 retirees across Qwest’s 14-state territory.

abstract: Harris Bank, Chicago’s third-largest bank, reported a 4 percent decline in second-quarter earnings partly as a result of competition. But the bank said it expects takeover upheaval at the city’s No. 2 bank, the LaSalle Bank, to help increase its business and said it is already trying to position itself for the inevitable shakeout.
lead_paragraph: Harris Bank, Chicago’s third-largest bank, reported a 4 percent decline in second-quarter earnings partly as a result of competition. But the bank said it expects takeover upheaval at the city’s No. 2 bank, the LaSalle Bank, to help increase its business and said it is already trying to position itself for the inevitable shakeout.

headline.main: As Bidders Circle LaSalle, Rival Bank Sees Upside

abstract: Parmalat, the Italian food giant that filed for bankruptcy in 2003, said Wednesday that New Jersey’s highest court rejected Citigroup‘s attempt to dismiss its $10 billion lawsuit accusing the bank of helping former management commit fraud. Parmalat, a major producer of milk, said the state supreme court rejected Citigroup’s appeal on the grounds that Parmalat brought the case in the wrong court.

headline.main: Court Rejects Citigroup Appeal, Parmalat Says

abstract: Australia’s Qantas Airways, recently the target of a failed $9 billion takeover bid, said Thursday it might split off some businesses or return billions of dollars to shareholders. Qantas told investors that as part of a “demerger” plan it was considering, it was reviewing options for its frequent flyer program and might sell its express freight joint venture and other operations.
lead_paragraph: Australia’s Qantas Airways, recently the target of a failed $9 billion takeover bid, said Thursday it might split off some businesses or return billions of dollars to shareholders. headline.main: Qantas May Sell Assets After Failed Buyout

abstract: Circuit City Stores, whose shares are at their lowest level in more than two years, is one of the most-attractive leveraged buyout candidates in the hardline retailing sector, several analysts say. Its stock has fallen below that $17 buyout offer from a Boston hedge fund that Circuit City rejected in 2005.
lead_paragraph: Circuit City Stores, whose shares are at their lowest level in more than two years, is one of the most-attractive leveraged buyout candidates in the hardline retailing sector, several analysts say. Its stock has fallen below that $17 buyout offer from a Boston hedge fund that Circuit City rejected in 2005.

headline.main: Will Private Equity Try Again for Circuit City?

abstract: Merrill Lynch employees may be looking a bit paler than usual this summer. That is because the investment bank has slashed the number of sick days that United States employees can take without consequences each year to three days from 40 — an amount that had been unusually generous by American standards — apparently in an effort to keep its bankers, traders and other workers from skipping off for long weekends at the Hamptons.

headline.main: Summertime Blues: Merrill Reins in Sick Days

abstract: Coca-Cola‘s president, Muhtar Kent, declined to comment Wednesday on speculation that the beverage giant might buy Glaceau, a maker of “enhanced water” drinks, but said his company was open to making acquisitions. “There are some rumors in the marketplace always about us acquiring certain companies,” Mr. Kent told reporters attending grand opening events in Atlanta for the new World of Coca-Cola attraction. “We do not comment on rumor and that’s all I can say.”

abstract: Google is closing in on an agreement to acquire Feedburner, a provider of Web content syndication tools, for about $100 million in cash, according to TechCrunch, which cited an unnamed source close to the deal. The technology blog, which first broke the news that Google would buy YouTube, said the Feedburner deal is expected to close in two to three weeks, and that “there is nothing that can really derail it at this point.” Feedburner, founded in 2003, has raised $10 million in venture capital from Portage Ventures, Mobius Venture Capital and Union Square Ventures.

headline.main: Google Close to Buying Feedburner, Report  Says

abstract: Another player has stepped into the brawl over the baseball card maker Topps, which agreed in March to be acquired by the private equity firm Madison Dearborn and Tornante, the investment vehicle of former chief executive of Disney, Michael Eisner. The new pitch is coming from Upper Deck, a rival baseball card company, which is offering $10.75 a share in cash for Topps — 10 percent more than the Madison Dearborn team’s $9.75-per-share bid, which had a value of $385 million. Three Topps directors are bitterly opposed to the latter offer, calling it too low, and have urged shareholders to reject it at a June 28 vote.
lead_paragraph: Another player has stepped into the brawl over the baseball card maker Topps, which agreed in March to be acquired by the private equity firm Madison Dearborn and Tornante, the investment vehicle of former chief executive of Disney, Michael Eisner. abstract: If you are having trouble telling the difference between hedge funds and investment banks these days, the latest ranking from Alpha magazine probably won’t help. In a further sign of how deeply Wall Street firms are getting into the hedge-fund business, the hedge fund arms of two bulge-bracket banks, J.P. Morgan Chase and Goldman Sachs, have the No. 1 and No. 2 positions on Alpha’s annual list of the biggest hedge funds. Top-ranked J.P. Morgan has $33 billion in hedge fund assets, putting it just above last year’s winner, Goldman, which oversees $32.5 billion.

abstract: Shareholder resistance is growing, in some cases at least, to take-private offers. (Just ask the folks trying to buy radio giant Clear Channel Communications.) Enter the lawyers at Weil, Gotshal & Manges, who are offering some advice on how buyout firms can counter that growing resistance. Many of the suggestions, in the law firm’s latest Private Equity Alert newsletter, are surely standard practice for buyout shoppers: Do due diligence, know who the big stockholders are, etc. But some points in the article — fittingly titled “The Great Pushback” — bear highlighting.

abstract: New houses sell, but for less
snippet: New houses sell, but for less
lead_paragraph: The headlines today say that new home sales leaped in April. The reality is not quite as good. The increase reported in partly a matter of seasonal adjustments, and may reflect price-cutting as well. The average and median sales prices were down substantially. The seasonally adjusted annual rate rose from 844,000 sales to 981,000. But actual monthly sales rose by just 12,000, to 92,000.

headline.main: Home Sales Stabilize

abstract: Russia won an incremental victory in the legal struggle for what remains of the foreign subsidiaries of Yukos. A Dutch court approved a request by the Russian bankruptcy administrator, Eduard K. Rebgun, to represent Yukos in court in the Netherlands. While most of Yukos’s assets have been unraveled and sold at auction, a company bank account in the Netherlands holding about $1 billion from the sale of a Lithuanian refinery is still in dispute. A Dutch court has yet to rule on Mr. Rebgun’s claim to the property, according to a statement by Yukos shareholders. The money is also claimed by Yukos shareholders and creditors.

abstract: Consumer prices fell at a slower pace in April, the government reported. Core consumer prices, which exclude fresh food, declined 0.1 percent from a year earlier. Core prices in Tokyo, a harbinger of nationwide prices, were unchanged for a second month, also in line with economists’ expectations.

abstract: General Motors said Thursday that it expected to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at Delphi, its former parts division. The company also said that it had received a new request for accounting documents from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has been investigating G.M.’s accounting practices for nearly two years.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said Thursday that it expected to take a $1 billion charge in the second quarter and pay a total of $7 billion to cover retirement costs for workers at Delphi, its former parts division. The company also said that it had received a new request for accounting documents from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which has been investigating G.M.’s accounting practices for nearly two years.

headline.main: G.M. Expects $1 Billion Charge for Delphi Costs

abstract: An Internet gambling site, BetonSports, pleaded guilty Thursday to federal racketeering charges and agreed to cooperate in a case against the company’s founder and other defendants, a prosecutor said. BetonSports admitted a “pattern of racketeering acts,” including mail and wire fraud, operating an illegal gambling business and money laundering, a statement from the United States attorney in St. Louis, Catherine L. Hanaway, said.

abstract: Morgan Stanley is reportedly close to completing fundraising for an $8 billion real estate investment fund, The Financial Times reported. It would be the securities firm’s largest real estate fund to date. The newspaper said that 40 percent of the investment bank’s sixth real estate fund will be invested in Japan. The fund is expected to close as early as next month amid strong demand from mostly non-Japanese investors, the Financial Times said.

headline.main: Morgan Stanley Fund Said to Approach $8 Billion

abstract: Stock in Greenlight Capital Re, a reinsurance company, jumped more than 20 percent in its market opening Thursday as the its ties to hedge fund manager David Einhorn seemed to be a draw for investors, MarketWatch reported. abstract: An internal document from Sallie Mae, the nation’s largest student lender, showed that the company sought a meeting with President Bush’s budget office about two months before the company’s chairman, Albert L. Lord, sold more than $18 million in shares. The Securities and Exchange Commission and the House education committee are investigating whether Mr. Lord had inside information about the president’s budget proposal, which was released in February and called for cuts in subsidies for companies participating in the federally guaranteed student loan program.

abstract: The Coca-Cola Company said Friday it would buy Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.1 billion. It would be Coke’s largest acquisition ever, and the price tag is more than the amount of cash Coke had on hand at the end of last quarter, meaning it will need to use debt to finance the all-cash deal. Shareholders seemed to find the deal refreshing: They bid up Coke shares by 1.4 percent in late-morning trading.
lead_paragraph: The Coca-Cola Company said Friday it would buy Glaceau, the maker of Vitaminwater, for $4.1 billion. Shareholders seemed to find the deal refreshing: They bid up Coke shares by 1.4 percent in late-morning trading.

headline.main: Coca-Cola Pulls Out the Stops for Glaceau Deal

In 2006, visits from the United States to all foreign destinations (excluding Canada and Mexico) were up 12.2 percent over the year 2000, to 30.3 million. abstract: The real estate company that bought two prominent apartment complexes on Manhattan’s Lower East Side is trying to make another major acquisition in the New York market. abstract: Amazing: Home prices are rising again in Boston and San Francisco.
snippet: Amazing: Home prices are rising again in Boston and San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: The latest housing price numbers have a tinge of hope — at least in some bubbly markets. The Standard & Poor’s/Case-Shiller indexes for March, out today, actually went up in the Boston and San Francisco regions. In each case, the bounce came after nine consecutive monthly declines. And the Portland and Seattle markets, which had shown signs of slipping although their year-over-year gains remained substantial, each showed improving month-over-month numbers.

headline.main: Housing Price Rebound?

abstract: Volvo has had plenty of admirers over the years, and we are not just talking about affluent Northeasterners who like its sensibly Swedish version of luxury. Renault of France and Fiat of Italy have, at various times, considered buying or merging with Volvo. With reports percolating that Ford Motor Company might put the business up for sale — it is part of Ford’s Premier Automotive Group, which has already sold Aston Martin — attention naturally turns to who else might cast an eye Volvo’s way.

abstract: Two decades ago, a favorable environment for junk-bond financing helped fuel a wave of leveraged buyouts. Citi’s equity strategists say they are feeling a bit of a flashback these days, as yields on risky debt are relatively low, making it cheaper to borrow money to take companies private. The atmosphere “is reminiscent of the L.B.O. heyday back in the latter 1980’s,” they wrote in a report published Tuesday. Citi’s analysts compared companies’ cash flows with junk-bond yields and found that certain sectors look especially ripe for buyouts: These included the commercial services industry (which includes waste management, employment services, etc.) and retailing.

headline.main: Retailers Turn Up on Citi’s Buyout List

snippet: Europe’s farmers are beginning to grow crops that can be turned into fuels meant to produce fewer emissions than gas or oil.
lead_paragraph: ARDEA, Italy — The previous growing season, this lush coastal field near Rome was filled with rows of delicate durum wheat, used to make high-quality pasta. Today it overflows with rapeseed, a tall, gnarled weedlike plant bursting with coarse yellow flowers that has become a new manna for European farmers: rapeseed can be turned into biofuel.

headline.main: Europe Pushes to Get Fuel From Fields
headline.print_headline: Europe Pushes to Get Fuel From Fields

abstract: South Korea’s industrial output rose in April, helped by increased exports of chips and cars. Manufacturing production jumped 3.1 percent from March, the largest gain in seven months, the National Statistical Office said. Output rose 6.7 percent from a year earlier. Corporate investment in factories surged 15.6 percent in April from a year earlier, the biggest gain since September 2006, the report showed. The figures also showed an index of economic indicators climbed 5.1 percent in April from a year earlier after rising 4.9 percent in March.

headline.main: Maker of a Well-Known but Risky Drug to Sell Shares

abstract: And then there were three. Bain Capital became the third buyout firm this week to quit a team of bidders considering an offer for the Coles Group, Australia’s second-largest retailer, leaving the Carlyle Group, the Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group in the running.
lead_paragraph: And then there were three. Bain Capital became the third buyout firm this week to quit a team of bidders considering an offer for the Coles Group, Australia’s second-largest retailer, leaving the Carlyle Group, the Blackstone Group and the Texas Pacific Group in the running.

headline.main: Bain Follows Suit and Abandons Coles Bid

abstract: The British government said Wednesday that it was selling a 2.2 billion pound ($4.3 billion) stake in British Energy, the nuclear power generator, as the company announced a sharp rise in profit and its first dividend since a state-backed rescue operation in 2002.
lead_paragraph: The British government said Wednesday that it was selling a 2.2 billion pound ($4.3 billion) stake in British Energy, the nuclear power generator, as the company announced a sharp rise in profit and its first dividend since a state-backed rescue operation in 2002.

headline.main: British Government to Sell $4.3 Billion Stake in British Energy

abstract: Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, Citigroup‘s largest individual shareholder and a vocal critic of the bank’s lagging performance, said he has confidence in Charles O. Prince III, the bank’s chief executive, and does not want to see a breakup of the bank.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, Citigroup‘s largest individual shareholder and a vocal critic of the bank’s lagging performance, said he has confidence in Charles O. Prince III, the bank’s chief executive, and does not want to see a breakup of the bank.

headline.main: Saudi Prince Shows Support for Citigroup Chief

abstract: Jo-Ann Stores is on the auction block with a price tag just shy of $1 billion, and final bids for the specialty chain are due in June, according to The Deal.com. Lehman Brothers, which was hired to run the auction for the Hudson, Ohio, company, one of the largest retailers of fabrics and arts and crafts supplies in the United States, has approached a select group of middle-market private equity firms, according to the report.
lead_paragraph: Jo-Ann Stores is on the auction block with a price tag just shy of $1 billion, and final bids for the specialty chain are due in June, according to The Deal.com. Lehman Brothers, which was hired to run the auction for the Hudson, Ohio, company, one of the largest retailers of fabrics and arts and crafts supplies in the United States, has approached a select group of middle-market private equity firms, according to the report.

headline.main: Private Equity Said to Circle $1 Billion Deal for Jo-Ann Stores

abstract: Post-nuptial agreements, once a novelty, are becoming increasingly more popular — and in some cases mandatory — in the world of hedge funds. The Financial Times reports that the post-nuptial agreement, where the married parties sign on the dotted line after the wedding bells have rung, is soaring in popularity among newly wealthy hedge fund managers.
lead_paragraph: Post-nuptial agreements, once a novelty, are becoming increasingly more popular — and in some cases mandatory — in the world of hedge funds. The Financial Times reports that the post-nuptial agreement, where the married parties sign on the dotted line after the wedding bells have rung, is soaring in popularity among newly wealthy hedge fund managers.

headline.main: Hedge Funds: With More Money Comes More Post-Nups

abstract: California’s First District Court of Appeal brushed aside claims Wednesday that Overstock.com, the online retailer, tried to gag a financial analysis company when it sued for libel two years ago.
lead_paragraph: California’s First District Court of Appeal brushed aside claims Wednesday that Overstock.com, the online retailer, tried to gag a financial analysis company when it sued for libel two years ago.

headline.main: Appeals Court Sides With Overstock in Gradient Suit

abstract: As deal-making sweeps through the real estate investment trust sector, Morgan Stanley has a made a bet on a real estate investment trust down under. The bank has agreed to buy the Investa Property Group of Australia, for 4.7 billion Australian dollars ($3.9 billion).
lead_paragraph: As deal-making sweeps through the real estate investment trust sector, Morgan Stanley has a made a bet on a real estate investment trust down under. The bank has agreed to buy the Investa Property Group of Australia, for 4.7 billion Australian dollars ($3.9 billion).

headline.main: Morgan Stanley to Buy Real Estate Investor

abstract: The Spanish government filed a lawsuit in a United States federal court on Wednesday seeking to block claims to any Spanish property recovered from shipwrecks by Odyssey Marine Exploration, whose biggest investors include several hedge funds.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish government filed a lawsuit in a United States federal court on Wednesday seeking to block claims to any Spanish property recovered from shipwrecks by Odyssey Marine Exploration, whose biggest investors include several hedge funds.

headline.main: Spain Files Suit Against Hedge Funds’ Treaure Hunter

abstract: Motorola on Wednesday revealed the final tally of votes in the proxy fight waged by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, and according to the numbers, Mr. Icahn lost soundly.
lead_paragraph: Motorola on Wednesday revealed the final tally of votes in the proxy fight waged by the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, and according to the numbers, Mr. Icahn lost soundly.

headline.main: Motorola Reveals Extent of Icahn’s Loss in Proxy Fight

abstract: Rupert Murdoch got the first show of support on Wednesday for his $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company when T. Rowe Price, Dow Jones’ largest outside shareholder, said that News Corporation‘s $60 a share bid is attractive and should be considered.
lead_paragraph: Rupert Murdoch got the first show of support on Wednesday for his $5 billion bid for Dow Jones & Company when T. Rowe Price, Dow Jones’ largest outside shareholder, said that News Corporation‘s $60 a share bid is attractive and should be considered.

headline.main: Dow Jones Shareholder Calls Murdoch’s Bid ‘Attractive’

abstract: Brocade Communications Systems has reached a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over charges that it illegally backdated its stock options, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources.
lead_paragraph: Brocade Communications Systems has reached a settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission over charges that it illegally backdated its stock options, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline.main: Brocade to Settle Backdating Charges for $7 Million

abstract: Northwest Airlines emerged from bankruptcy protection Thursday, and its new shares were set to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speaking with the Star Tribune, Doug Steenland, the company’s chief executive, acknowledged that the airline considered various options during its Chapter 11 stay, including a merger with another airline — such as Delta Air Lines — or bringing in a private equity investor.
lead_paragraph: Northwest Airlines emerged from bankruptcy protection Thursday, and its new shares were set to begin trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Speaking with the Star Tribune, Doug Steenland, the company’s chief executive, acknowledged that the airline considered various options during its Chapter 11 stay, including a merger with another airline — such as Delta Air Lines — or bringing in a private equity investor.

headline.main: Northwest Airlines Exits Bankruptcy Protection

abstract: Microsoft's version of the multi-touch computer adds one very cool, though impractical, twist: interaction with other electronics.
snippet: Microsoft's version of the multi-touch computer adds one very cool, though impractical, twist: interaction with other electronics.
lead_paragraph: It was just about the strangest call I'd ever received from Microsoft. "We have a new product we want to show you," said the PR woman (I'm paraphrasing). "But we can't tell you what it is, or even what category. But it's truly revolutionary. It's going to change the way people work with their computers."

headline.main: Much Ado About Microsoft's Surface Computer
headline.kicker: From the Desk of David Pogue

abstract: Genesco, the maker of Johnston & Murphy and Dockers brand shoes, has received several preliminary takeover offers from private-equity firms that could rival a rejected $1.2 billion hostile offer from Foot Locker, the New York Post reported Thursday citing unnamed sources.
lead_paragraph: Genesco, the maker of Johnston & Murphy and Dockers brand shoes, has received several preliminary takeover offers from private-equity firms that could rival a rejected $1.2 billion hostile offer from Foot Locker, the New York Post reported Thursday citing unnamed sources.

headline.main: Buyout Firms Are Said to Court Genesco

abstract: As Wachovia revs its deal-making machinery, the bank seems to be spreading its advisory work around — though the names are familiar ones for the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank. A year after its $25 billion purchase of Golden West Financial, it turned to some different firms for financial advice and legal counsel on Thursday’s $6.8 billion deal for A.G. Edwards.
lead_paragraph: As Wachovia revs its deal-making machinery, the bank seems to be spreading its advisory work around — though the names are familiar ones for the Charlotte, N.C.-based bank. A year after its $25 billion purchase of Golden West Financial, it turned to some different firms for financial advice and legal counsel on Thursday’s $6.8 billion deal for A.G. Edwards.

headline.main: Wachovia Switches Up on Deal Advisers

abstract: Just how Canadian is telecom mogul Richard Li?
lead_paragraph: Just how Canadian is telecom mogul Richard Li?

headline.main: Richard Li May Join Bell Canada Bidders

abstract: A previous bid to invest in Delphi may have fallen through earlier this year, but the bankrupt auto parts maker may have found a new set of backers. In a regulatory filing on Thursday, Highland Capital Management said that it had reached a confidentiality agreement with the company, the first step in potentially creating an investment plan as Delphi prepares to exit bankruptcy protection.
lead_paragraph: A previous bid to invest in Delphi may have fallen through earlier this year, but the bankrupt auto parts maker may have found a new set of backers. In a regulatory filing on Thursday, Highland Capital Management said that it had reached a confidentiality agreement with the company, the first step in potentially creating an investment plan as Delphi prepares to exit bankruptcy protection.

headline.main: Has Delphi Found New Backers?

abstract: Whether or not the world needed another profile of Carl Icahn (who, depending on the era, is variously described as a “financier,” a “corporate raider” or an “activist investor”), Fortune magazine has a long one in its latest issue. The general thesis is that although the “New Icahn” may be different from the old one, his, ahem, expansive personality hasn’t changed that much through the years.

The general thesis is that although the “New Icahn” may be different from the old one, his, ahem, expansive personality hasn’t changed that much through the years.

headline.main: Carl Icahn, $50 Billion and the ‘Mollusk’

abstract: William Lerach, the star plaintiff’s attorney who has become a target of a federal investigation into illegal kickbacks by Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, has told clients and others that he will retire, Fortune’s Legal Pad reported Wednesday evening and The Washington Post on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: William Lerach, the star plaintiff’s attorney who has become a target of a federal investigation into illegal kickbacks by Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, has told clients and others that he will retire, Fortune’s Legal Pad reported Wednesday evening and The Washington Post on Thursday.

headline.main: Plaintiffs’ Lawyer Lerach to Step Down, Reports Say

abstract: Remember when dot-com companies were being criticized for underpricing their initial public offerings in order to create first-day trading pops, and helping expand the market bubble? The World Bank thinks much the same thing is happening now — in China.
lead_paragraph: Remember when dot-com companies were being criticized for underpricing their initial public offerings in order to create first-day trading pops, and helping expand the market bubble? The World Bank thinks much the same thing is happening now — in China.

headline.main: Is China Lowballing Its I.P.O.’s?

abstract: Shares of Molson Coors Brewing were up more than 2 percent to $92.08 on Thursday, but it was the frothy action in the company’s options that raised eyebrows at OptionMonster.com. The Web site noted heavy trading in June options to buy Molson Coors shares at $95 apiece, a move that it attributed to “takeover chatter.” These options would see a big jump in value if Molson were acquired or taken private at a premium in the next month.
lead_paragraph: Shares of Molson Coors Brewing were up more than 2 percent to $92.08 on Thursday, but it was the frothy action in the company’s options that raised eyebrows at OptionMonster.com. headline.main: Is Molson Coors a Takeover Play?

abstract: After learning of Wachovia‘s plan to buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion, Wall Street immediately set about betting on which regional brokerage firms might be acquired next.
lead_paragraph: After learning of Wachovia‘s plan to buy A.G. Edwards for $6.8 billion, Wall Street immediately set about betting on which regional brokerage firms might be acquired next.

headline.main: Who’s Next: Regional Brokers

abstract: Lehman Brothers plans a $500 million initial public offering of a private-equity fund next month, even after similar vehicles by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Management have struggled to return investors’ money, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources.
lead_paragraph: Lehman Brothers plans a $500 million initial public offering of a private-equity fund next month, even after similar vehicles by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Apollo Management have struggled to return investors’ money, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources.

headline.main: Lehman to List Buyout Fund Next Month, Report Says

abstract: Mercury Interactive became the second company to pay a fine to settle charges that it illegally backdated stock options, regulators announced on Thursday. But the Securities and Exchange Commission said it is also suing four former executives, alleging fraud and deception to to enrich themselves and select employees.
lead_paragraph: Mercury Interactive became the second company to pay a fine to settle charges that it illegally backdated stock options, regulators announced on Thursday. But the Securities and Exchange Commission said it is also suing four former executives, alleging fraud and deception to to enrich themselves and select employees.

headline.main: Mercury to Settle Backdating Charges for $28 Million
